author: Lorduncan

description.text:
WARNING: Wear eye protection while assembling this in case the spring is uncooperative and decides to attack you.

The spring clip on the back of a Phiaton bluetooth headphones was to made too flimsy to stand up to normal use and snapped off. Since I didn't really want to spend another $75 to replace the headphones, and all the products I could find were for MUCH heavier devices (e.g. pagers or flip-phones), I just spent some "hobby" time designing a replacement that I could 3D-print and epoxy on where the old spring clip broke off. This could be used on any small device that needs to be clipped onto clothing. Hope it's useful to someone.

You'll need a roll pin that's about 1mm diameter and about 20mm (2cm) long. Then you can "permanently borrow" the spring from a small hair clip (see photo).

The assembly tool is optional, but it might make it easier to hold the spring in place while you get the roll pin through the hinge.

Again, wear eye protection while you're assembling this!!! The spring will fly off and get you if you don't.

title: Anet A8 LED strip mount under X axis

description.text:
This thing holds an sticky-back LED strip to the underside of the X-axis of the Anet A8 to put more light on the bed. It requires four M4 screws to clamp the assembly to the X-axis. The other sections friction-fit together (calibrate your extruder!), but you will probably want to glue the parts together.

The projection from the bottom of the left bracket is intended to prevent the bracket from fouling on the Anet A8 when lowering the X-axis--the projection will self-align the bracket so it doesn't get stuck. You may want to print a mirror of this bracket so that both sides have the projection. If your brackets are tightly screwed down, the lamp is less likely to move so you might not need the anti-fouling projection.

remixed_from.author: maximscy
remixed_from.title: kossel800 k800 ver.hero delta 3dprinter deltabot arm

title: DELTARUNNER, the universal delta 3d printer carriage for kossel, mini, k800 etc.

description.text:
https://youtu.be/61O8Exj6fko

I've been playing with lot of wheels, many extrusion profile types, mostly 2020 with different slots, and I got tired of downloading and adjusting carriages all the time. I played with magnetic arms as well, so I also had to reprint my carriages when switching to fisheye arms.

After months of trial and error, I'm sharing my final design, tested on my own delta with great success. It is a direct replacement for most fisheye bearing or magnets based delta printers like Kossel, Mini, Flsun, etc. With the right Face, it could adapt to many others.

This carriage comes in 3 parts, and is "universal", as long as it is running on a 2020 extrusion (although 1515 or 3030 may work as well, untested).

For the perfectionists, an optional guide can be printed, it will help align the face horizontally and center it against the aluminium extrusion

Specs & Features:

1) 3 wheels (M3, M4 or M5 bolts, size can vary from diameter 12mm to 40mm)
2) Precise & strong grip system with slider (using M3 screw & bearing).
3) Centerable Face (current faces available: M3/40mm; M3/42mm; M3/50mm; Magnetic 46mm spaced (K800...))
4) Solid: when tightened, the 3 face bolts makes the whole carriage stronger.

Non 3d printed parts:

  • 1 x 623ZZ bearing (10mmx4mmx3mm) (I'd recommend to get one, but you can also, instead, use a washer outside the bolt hole and tighten this way. It will be harder to loose the grip, though)
  • 1 long M3 bolt (+/- 45 to 65 mm) depending on wheels sizes;
  • 3 shorter M3 bolts. They need to be short enough NOT to go through both the Face and the Base, so it wont touch the aluminium extrusions.
  • 6 x M3 nuts
  • 3 wheels and the bolts, nuts and washers that go with them;
  • Some small pliers to help with the bearing installation.

What to download:

You need 3 parts: Base, Slider & Face. Base and Slider comes in 3 flavors: M3, M4 or M5. Pick the right type based on your wheels inner diameter. Pick the face based on the distance between two rods on your printer. If it is neither 40 nor 42mm nor 50mm, or if you're using magnetic arms, you may still adjust, or download Face base or GT2 Kit to create your own face.

Wanna ask me print it? https://www.3dhubs.com/service/lc2-officewarzone

Resolution:

0.1 to 0.2mm

Infill:

30% minimum

Notes:

Fan Duct (or supports) needed.

I would recommend PLA. ABS can be quite brittle sometimes. Reinforced filament is not necessary, but why not :-)

Assembly Instructions:

I recommend NOT to pre-drill the Slider hole. Tight holes will help avoiding backlash.

  • Fit the 2 nuts in the back of Base. Use a lighter if needed to warm the nut and have it slide in and stay;
  • Same for Slider: One nut to fit the same way. + Two others that need to be pushed vertically. Ensure these two are aligned with the hole.
  • Snap the bearing in the Base. Slide the long M3 bolt. Use some pliers to hold the nut in place while screwing the bolt through it. Screw the bolt all way in.
  • Install your wheels. No detailed instructions provided: it depends on the wheels you bought! Just ensure you're using standard hex bolts otherwise the bolt head may not fit inside the Slider.
  • Insert the Slider in the Base, start screwing the bolt through the two nuts. There you are; adjustable grip!
  • Prepare the Face by inserting the two nuts in the back. Verify that they are correctly aligned.
  • Screw the 3 shorter bolts in but do not tighten them yet.
  • Place the assembled carriage around the aluminium extrusion and tighten the 3 wheels around it;
  • Adjust the Face so that it sits perfectly horizontal and centered; tighten the screws.
  • Verify if the wheels are still sliding. The middle bolts tightening the Slider, you may need to do some adjustments here. Always unscrew the middle bolt before adjusting the carriage grip.
  • Enjoy!

I'm familiar with Sketchup. I just love it since I found this trick: work with meters instead of millimeters. Why? Because merging complex shapes will work. Sketchup seems to have an hardcoded resolution limit and strange and annoying things happens in small details when using millimeters.

description.text:
The filament monitor on the HICTOP 3DP08 is on the far left below the spool mount above the printer. Not only was it hard to get filament through it, I ran into issues with it binding when printing on the opposite end of the printer and creating jaggy edges on my prints.

This centers it below the spool and moves it out a bit so it feeds more tangential from the spool and more directly into the extruder. I also find that it's easier to load filament into it.

My first attempt blocked the second mounting screw, so no good. I redid it and moved it, so they didn't line up, and cut off the corners. This had the added bonus of being able to print the part without any supports.

First I took a picture of my last good clip, imported the picture as a canvas in Fusion 360 which I then traced. I then extruded it to the desired thickness and added the recess and hole for latching.

title: 2014 Ram Truck Phone Holder, Business card slot conversion
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Phone cradle for 2014 and earlier Ram Trucks.
This cradle clips to the business card holder in the center console and fits an iPhone 6 with a KX case. This holds the phone upright and out of the way, inside the console. Keeps your phone visible but out of the way of the controls on the dash board.

Print in two pieces and snap together for the cleanest print. Can be printed in one piece as well, but the supports leave a little mess to clean up.

Now with cutouts to save on materials and time.

author: Ajakeski

description.text:
So, I was looking through for a good bed leveler. I kept finding bed levelers to hold the Pittsburgh (cen-tech) "1 In. Travel Machinist's Dial Indicator" (item #623) or "AE/Metric Digital Indicator" (item #93295).

All of these were different widths for different printers, not to mention, they just sit on top of the bar, which seems to me that would be too easy to mess up the measurement.

So, I set out to make something easier. Of course, nothing is going to be 'real accurate' with the flex in the bars, and the flex in the plastic, but, this one (IMHO) is about as accurate as it's going to get.

This will fit most(?) printers with 2 horizontal bars for the X-axis. I also made the clips to hook on to 8 or 10mm bars. (I don't have 10mm bars so I haven't been able to test those, so, someone please let me know :) )

Check out the pictures and STL, it should all be pretty self--explanatory.

description.text: Every 3d designer must design a shower hook, so here is my contribution. It's a minimalist design, using under 1/2 meter of PLA and no supports.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print it with the hook flat against the print bed (see the Cura screenshot) for maximum strength. I printed in PLA for recyclability.

I designed it to have a strong shower hook and a strong squeegee peg. By printing with the shower hook flat against the print bed, the design takes advantage of the relative XY plane strength of FFM printing. By being a 45 degree peg with a curved connection into the other hook, the squeegee hook takes advantage of a bit of the XY strength and avoids concentrating stress where the peg meets the hook.

A shower squeegee is used to wipe water off the shower walls at the end of your shower, so the salts in the water don't form stains on the shower walls and floor.

description.text:
This is a counter weight attachment designed for the Glock 43. It adds weight to the front of the gun reducing recoil and effectively reducing the target re-aquisition time. All edges have been chamfered so there won't be any inference with the draw.

It's divided into two halves, fits snugly around the front of the trigger guard, and is held tight with (4) 8mm diameter by 3mm thick magnets. The small circular pockets hold the magnets and the front pockets hold the lead weight. I was able to get perfectly fit lead blocks by soaking a couple "sacrificial mold" prints in water, lining the pocket with aluminum foil, and pouring lead the in. I'd recommend using epoxy to secure the magnets and lead in place.

title: Improved Prusa heated platform leveling thing

description.text: I wanted to improve on my bed leveling "Thing" and reduce parts and costs. So, as I built my next prusa I made this change.

Instructions Parts list: 4 - thingiverse.com/thing:6599 M3 Rosettes
16 - M3 nuts
4 - M3x16 bolts
2 - Servalite WSH-8566U Sliding Bolt Spring w/Dog (Cut each into 4 equal parts) and parts-bin the "Dog"
4 - M3 flat washers I applied it to:
thingiverse.com/thing:10754 AlephObjects Aluminum bed plate 1) Print the rosettes
2) Put M3 nut into rosetta
3) Run M3x16 screw into rosetta (nut side) to head
4) Screw M3 nut to rosetta and tighten
5) Put 1 of the 8 spring portions onto the bolt
6) Screw this assembly upward through the aluminum plate
7) Put on second of 8 portions of spring and one flat washer onto bolt
--- repeat 1-7 this for all 4 screws
8) Put the heated bed over the 4 screws
9) Put on 2 M3 nuts onto screws atop the heated bed
10) Adjust the height and lock the twin nuts as "jam nuts" Hopefully the balance is evident at this point. The TXT file is just these text. Thigiverse wont allow just a pic to represent a thing The Servalite WSH-8566U Sliding Bolt Spring w/Dog was purchased at OSH for $1.

comments.text: Like many others, I've found that if your frame is highly square, and you are using prusa style x ends, you can forgo the adjustment screws, and simply mount your heated bed on 1/2" nylon spacers.

Remix of the Panucatt Devices Simple mounting bracket -STL to allow the Viki2 to be attached to the underside of a 20mm extrusion.

Note that the part is not symmetrical - there is a distinct "left" and "right" part because of the offset and rounded edges.

Designed in OpenSCAD.

If you wish to alter the source (that creates the "left" bracket"), keep in mind you will need to mirror the output part to create the companion "right" bracket.

print_settings.Notes:: Can't wait for the right bolts to show up now so I can actually mount this thing!

description.text:
I love the Tevo 2020 cross frame brace made by Radem (thing:1657193) , but in order for me to use it on the Anet A2 I needed to make room for the metal brackets the A2 uses in the corners.

While I was at it I figured some personalization needed to happen so I could use this to fit all 4 sides, so I've also added a design with zip-tie holes so that you can route the wires from the Y motor and switch along the gusset allowing more slack in the wire's leading to the mainboard so that I can raise it up higher allowing more room for additional Z bracing to come.

I've also added some versions with the text as well just because I could. :)

I do plan on creating a design with a cable chain mount as well, once I figure out which chain design I want to use.

Edit 03-31-17 - just added some photos to show that the zip-tie's fit perfectly, and work great!

Printer:

Anet A2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I printed mine using PLA+ @220 for the HE. and 55 for the bed lined with buildtak.

I do recommend support's touching the build surface so the tabs that fit into the 2020 slot's have support, the rest should be fine without any.

Super stuck, should probably have lowered the bed temp a bit, but they fit absolutely perfect!

I did need to ream out the holes for the 2020 side of things to get an M5 to go through easily but the one's I added worked without needing to be resized.

Can't wait for the right bolts to show up now so I can actually mount this thing!
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/101wCqNA3iI

I purchased a Meanwell nes-350-12 power supply for the printer. It comes with a plastic strip over the terminals. Obviously it's designed to be placed in a rack/enclosure. Since those terminals are accessible to anyone's fingers I felt I need to design a cover for it.
The cover design is pretty straightforward. It slips on easily. The power cable is retained by a small clip and two screws. Try using the 1/2" long 1/8" self tapping screws.
There are two holes for 14 gage wires to carry the DC current out.
I use two 1/8" brackets to mount the cover the bottom of the makerslide. This cover design is the latest after several previous iterations. The features where the M4 screws sit were reinforced with the ribs. Right now it is able to hold the entire Hadron printer weight by the power chord without snapping.

Print the cover with support. I use slic3r 0910b. 70% infill, 2.5 mm rectilinear grid support. It takes 3.5-4 hours to print. Once it's cleaned use two M4x6 flat head screws to mount it. Because there is plastic in the clamp I put a dab of blue loctite on the screws

My students have been obsessed with two things lately, Pokemon Go and fidget spinners. So I decided to combine the two and create a fidget spinner that looks like a Pokeball.

You will need to print the following:

  • (1) Base.stl - I printed mine in black
  • (2) Middle.stl - I printed mine in white
  • (4) Pokehalf.stl - I printed two in red and two in white.

UPDATE - I added a file that holds pennies (Base_ForPenny.stl)

UPDATE #2 - I added a file that holds M8 nuts (Base_ForM8.stl)

UPDATE #3 - I added a new middle button that is a little taller (should allow for a better spin)

You will also need three 608zz bearings (unless you print the Base_ForPenny file)

Once you have 3D printed all of the parts, start with the base and press-fit the 608zz bearings into the three openings. I used a small vise to help with this.

Next, "snap" the Pokehalf pieces in the openings around the bearings. These should be a tight fit, so a small amount of sanding may be required. You might also want to use super glue to permanently place the Pokehalf pieces, but with my prototypes, this was not needed.

Finally, press the Middle pieces into the center of the middle bearing on each side.

If you have any trouble, check out the pictures, or ask questions.

Now go out there and spin your Pokeball to your heart's content!

remixed_from.author: mike_mattala
remixed_from.title: NUT JOB | Nut, Bolt, Washer and Threaded Rod Factory

title: Filament Guide with Pulley Sheaves for 608 Bearings

description.text:
This is a filament guide with two pulleys. I'm using this to route filament between a customized food dehydrator (to keep filament dry during printing) and a Lulzbot Mini.

The base clamp is a "friction fit" for 1/4" material (in my case, the plexiglass top to my printer enclosure), using flex in the plastic for clamping force. I designed it for PCTPE, a nylon which has quite a bit of flex. It should also work well as-is with ABS. The gap angle may be too tight for a more rigid material like PLA, but the Sketchup design file is included if you want to change the gap.

The pulley sheaves provide a press fit for a standard 608 bearing, and have a retainer stop to center the bearing in the sheave. The sheaves slightly overhang the bearing, so (2) standard M8 washers are needed on either side of the bearings (4 total) to space them and the sheaves away from the support. I used standard metal washers here, but printed M8 washers or spacers would be an improvement.

The M8 nuts and bolts were generated from the parametric "Nut Job" customizer design linked as a remix source.

I printed all parts from Taulman PCTPE. I used a 0.15 layer thickness for the nuts and bolts, and 0.25 for everything else. Infill at 80% on nuts and bolts, 60% on all others. Everything prints without support, but the bolt holes are cleaner with support.

Sketchup design file included for the support bracket and pulley sheaves.

comments.text: What is that filament drier you are using?
comments.author: BrayChristopher

comments.text: It's called a "PrintDry" drier, which started as a kickstarter project and is now sold via their web site (printdry dot com).
comments.author: BrayChristopher

comments.text: Hmm... Did you do some post processing on the STL files from the nut/bolt generator? The edges look cleaner than the aliasing that comes out the marching cubes renderer and you got the file sizes down considerably. Good job!
comments.author: deadsy

comments.text: My apologies...  Upon checking, the nuts/bolts were from mike_mattala's "Nut Job" collection.  I will update the description and link.  Too many good models, I can't keep them straight!  :-)
comments.author: deadsy

comments.text: That's a pity. I thought you might have had some post-processing STL secrets. I suppose I'll still have to write something better than marching cubes.
comments.author: ScottW1

author: ScottW1

This is my version of a Pagoda-2 Antenna assembly jig.

I've found it print's fine in just PLA.

Possibly more Beretta 9MM items to be uploaded such as mag stock and modded to hold electronics.

title: Master Airscrew RC Plane Spinner for 3Dlabprint p-38 Lightning RC propeller 9
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
*these spinners all currently spin CCW (tractor) if viewing the plane from the front. To reverse simply mirror the print in your preferred slicing software.

THESE DESIGNS ARE PRINTED AND USED ENTIRELY AT YOUR OWN RISK
obviously high RPM is dangerous and can cause shrapnel in excess of 120 MPH (depending on rpm, could be even higher)
Use these prints at your own risk, they work for me and my application spinning at 10K rpm, Idk if they will work for you and make no claim to safety.

The master airscrew 3 blade props had a wider diameter face and would not mount in the included STL files from 3dlabprint, so I designed these from scratch to work with the propeller I have.

Also using the D4023 850kv Brushless Outrunner Motor

UPDATE:

I also included a 2 blade version, the configuration I am using these requires a bolt between the propeller and spinner (the propeller does not mate directly to the face of the spinner)

However your application demands shouldn't be too difficult to setup depending on the propeller you have.

the propeller is not my design or original work https://grabcad.com/library/rc-airplane-prop-and-mold The propeller belongs to Spencer Stromberg, I made some basic edits to the file for my own use check out his stuff on grabcad

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Fine (.15 .2 or lower)

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Layout on bed as shown. Simply copy, mirror, and print. Print on HQ settings, low layer height, low speed.

Had issues printing with Cura, slic3r worked best for some reason, always verify layers are printing as desired.
Designed in Fusion 360

author: inse

title: Hadron ORD Bot filament holder assembly and filament guide

description.text:
I designed this filament holder a while ago. It was specifically designed for the octave filament being sold by Amazon. Off course there are various spools being sold today. This will accommodate many more types (like the one sold by automation technologies). It is used together with the filament guide. Te guide has a "NO GRAB" text recessed into it, so people would not lift the printer by this - it will not break though.
To mount the filament hub on the filament bracket I use a 1/4-20 hex bolt 4 inches long. To prevent loosening I put a dab of blue loctite on the screw.
The filament nut and hub are joined by a bayonet type feature. You'll have to assemble the spool to the hub push the nut on, then rotate it clockwise until it snaps in. This will prevent the nut from rattling off. Even with a full 1 kg filament spool this balances well.
The filament holder bracket is mounted by four M5x12 cap screws. I drilled holes through the Hadron back plate and used the misumi nuts to mount the filament holder. As an alternative method you can drill and tap m5 holes into the back plate.
The bracket has 1/4-20 threads in the base. This will mate with the hex bolt threads.
Once everything assembled thread the filament through the filament guide's slot, then bring it to the front though the 45 degree hole.
The construction might seem complicated, but believe me this is not the first iteration. I've had long prints and when the filament spool is not constrained well and it'll run and bundle up the filament that is the last thing you want in a 27 hour print.
This worked perfectly for me; hope you'll enjoy it too.
Print the bracket, hub and nut without support, oriented as shown. Print the filament guide upside down (as shown) with with support. I use slic3r 0910b. 70% infill, 2.5 mm rectilinear grid support

description.text:
A friend of mine is having a Luchador themed birthday bar crawl, along with the mask and cape i have ordered, I figured these rings would go well with my costume. I am currently printing them and may have to make changes.

The rings are sized for someone with the following finger diameters

Index: 21mm
Middle: 21mm
Ring: 20mm
Pinkey: 18mm

I am printing this in 3DSolutech White PLA. No Raft, No Supports (This was a mistake, you WILL need supports.)

EDIT: the dot over the "i" was not connected to anything, and the middle finger needed to be 21.5mm, also, somme of the letters were not connected very well to the rings.

Version 2 now includes a platform for the letters, and the triangles that were between the rings and below the letters have been filled in for stability. The middle finger is now 21.5mm, and the dot over the "i" in "Libre" has been connected to the i's main body.

description.text:
*****UPDATE August 2017 - I ran into issues with the closed sides on my original version, so I made one with open sides to accommodate larger prints. I also (per request) made an angled tealight version.
I would not recommend using an actual tealight, but it will fit the typical Ikea brand candle tealights, including the holder, and will of course fit the preferred LED tealights. The LED versions really work well, actually! The frame gap situates the lithophane in a relatively vertical position, and new versions provide an angled option instead of completely vertical. Sides were left open to accommodate slightly larger prints - the original was intended to house a 5.5 x 5.5" lithophane.

I am using a MakerSelect v2 using no support, no raft, 0.8 mm wall thickness, 0.1 mm layer height, print speed of 35-50 mm/s using Inland PLA from Micro Center.
Constructive commentary gladly accepted - enjoy!

description.text:
This a remix of "Incomplete Build Model" by Knwong.
Knwong only provided a .x3g files. After printing it was not working properly. I also made it shorter as the movement of the feeding tube is limited by the cover.
He also didn’t provide the mounting pin; therefore, I designed this one. Aligned the groves with the mounting bracket; then ¼ turn with a flat screw driver to lock it in place.
I also designed a small ring to hold the tube in place so this last one doesn’t jump out of the holder during printing
Here is a video showing the free motion this modification is offering:
https://youtu.be/M3hb1jzsWiQ
Since then, I never had a fail print due to filament tangling or tube not hold in place.
Happy printing

print_settings.Notes:: The mount should be possible to successfully print without supports on a printer with good bridging performance.

description.text:
This is a remix of Part A26 of the Eclips3D - High Resolution CoreXY 3D Printer
by DDeGonge888, modified to accommodate the v2 and v3 versions of the Azteeg X5 Mini.

This also adds in the features from the Mini USB & Switch Mount, for a SPST Snap in Rocker Switch (e.g. this one from Amazon) and a Mini USB B 5 PIN Male to Female Extension Data Cable Adapter Joiner Coupler Cord (e.g. this one from Amazon; note that most short extensions you'll see are 25 cm, you need one that's slightly longer: 1 ft). This mount fully encloses the switch, and has a provision for the cables to exit the mount body.

There's an optional "bumper" for the opposite side of the frame so that the printer will lean evenly when tipped on that side.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 micron

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Contracted this out to a printing house to be printed in PLA/PHA.

The mount should be possible to successfully print without supports on a printer with good bridging performance.

In order to secure the controller to the mount and the mount to the extrusion, you will need the following additional hardware:

2 x M5*10mm Hex Socket Cap Screws
2 x M5 T-slot Nuts
4 x M3*10mm Hex Socket Cap Screws
4 x M3 Hex Nuts

Press-fit the USB extension cable in from the front (flat) side by threading the smaller male end through the mount opening and seat the female end by pressing it flush against a flat surface, such as a desk. It should fit snugly and stay put without adjustment, but filing and/or glue may be required from variances in printing or your USB cable.

I used two JST pigtails as the connectors for my switch (so I can dismount the controller or the power supply without getting held up short). The female side matches up with a male connector on my LED strip, the other mates with a pigtail on the power supply.

If you print the optional "bumper" you will need an additional:

2 x M5*10mm Hex Socket Cap Screws
2 x M5 T-slot Nuts

author: 3d4uandme

description.text:
(case not included, yet) I made this for a relative who had a rhino awareness day at their workplace, raising money for charities which help to defend rhinos against poaching. It is based on the Rhino model that Yahoo JP uploaded - credit for the sculpting goes to them only! It is hollowed out and a channel is added underneath for money to fall into a box it is mounted upon (although it doesn't need a box to function). The hole in the top is made to fit UK coins with room to spare. I suggest that if you use this thing, and you are not in Britain, you find out the largest diameter and thickness among your country's coinage. Measurements for the hole are below. If anyone knows how to print supports in Cura so that they are not so difficult to remove, please tell me! These measurements were taken from Blender Length (backside to front of nose): 171.403 mm
Width (left side to right side): 62.840 mm
Height (soles of feet to hump on back): 97.329 mm
Hole length: 36.16 mm
Hole width: 3.42 mm Of course, you can scale it in your slicer or in Blender. As per CC-BY, please attribute YahooJAPAN and myself if you redistribute or make derivatives of this thing.

Despite the fact that synthetic ivory and keratin can be made, rhinos and elephants are still poached on a massive, brutal, and organised scale by criminal gangs with vast resources; fueled by demand from all over the world, from people who believe that rhino horn and elephant tusk has specific healing and aphrodisiac properties, and who adore its beauty when carved and polished. It is a valuable status symbol (but contributes no positive value to any society), in the same way that luxury cars and big houses are status symbols in the Western world. If you would like to support the fight against rhino and elephant poaching, please get informed and spread the word:

  • Most of the people who buy into the market don't know the consequences. Abhor rhino horn and elephant tusk products.

  • Appeal to your political leaders for action to disrupt the markets which back poaching.

  • The more people know, the more power there will be behind the campaign against poaching.
    • If you would like to offer financial support, three charities/non-profits I'd suggest (of course, there are many more) are:

  • Kariega - South African game reserve which has been affected by rhino poaching, and has set up a foundation dedicated to rhino conservation.

  • David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust - Elephant and rhino rescue and rehabilitation program in East Africa (based in Kenya).

  • Rhino Ark Charitable Trust - A trust which is geared towards helping humans live in harmony with rhinos and elephants.
    • See also:

  • Rhino economics - A suggested alternative approach to disrupting the markets backing this poaching.

  • Rhino Information Centre - Get the facts. This is a massive archive of relevant publications.

The two sides are printed together and subsequently glued together. It was made to be fixed to a base (wooden or otherwise) which may also have a case inside in order to fit more money. If you do not affix it to a base, and it is filled with money, the center of mass may be high once filled, and it will easily fall over. Also mind the hole in the bottom. The print needs to be high quality if it is going to be displayed in a public place. As a result, the print may take many hours to do (mine took about 6 or 7 hours per side on an Ultimaker). "High quality" means slow down your print move speed substantially from its default. You should also make the layers thin. But it should be safe to lower the density of internal and external supports substantially. If you are unsatisfied with the quality after an hour or two, you should cancel your print prematurely to save time. Also, a raft or heated bed is essential - the parts need to fit together, and warping is not acceptable unless you want to use some sort of filler.

author: Ansley

description.text: Scanned with the MakerBot Digitizer Desktop 3D Scanner

When you saw the article title, may be you will laugh: charge lipo battery is so easy. Connect the battery to charger is done. Is it really easy? Let us to see the professionals give the complete charge lipo battery needing attention.

charge lipo battery

  1. Only use charger designed for lithium polymer/Lion battery. Do not use a NIMH/ NICD/ LIFEPO4/ LEAD ACID charger. If the charger can support different battery types. Be absolutely sure to select the Lithium polymer (Lipo) mode on the charger. Failure to do so may cause a fire, which may result in personal injury and property damage.

  2. User should Always charge Batteries in an open area away from flammable materials, liquids and surfaces.

  3. Never charge Batteries inside of the model.

  4. Never charge batteries below freezing (0°C, 32°F)

  5. Never charge Batteries that are hot to the touch (above 100°F). DO NOT handle Batteries until they are cool.

  6. User should Always set the charger to the proper cell count and/or voltage listed on Batteries' labels.

  7. User should Always set the charger to the amp charge rate as listed on Batteries' labels.

The charger should never be set to charge Batteries at a rate greater than 1C (One (1) times the capacity of Batteries in amp hours) unless another C rate is specified in the manufacturer's product documentation or the rate is preset as part of a specific battery and charger combination. DO NOT alter the charge rate once charging has begun.

  1. Never overcharge Batteries beyond the capacity listed on Batteries' labels.

  2. Never overcharge batteries over their rated maximal voltage (4.2V/cell for LiPo).

  3. It must choose series charging if two or more battery packs be connected in series for using.

  4. Use suitable and good quality chargers, please don't use cheap and low quality chargers, use the professional Lithium polymer charger to charge the Gens ace & Tattu battery. When charging, please make sure the surroundings is clean, without sundries around. Don't charge without monitoring. Using lipo sack is suggested when charging to ensure the charging safety. Stop charging timely when the battery is fully charged. Do not connect the charger and the battery for a long time when the battery is fully charged. We will not be responsible for any personal in jury and property lost or any kind accident that caused by improper charging.

This support will help you fix your deuligne kit to your Ultimaker. Deuligne kit available on Snootlab: http://shop.snootlab.com/lang-en/snootlab-shields/140-lcd-kit-for-ultimaker.html Wiki: http://wiki.ultimaker.com/Deuligne_LCD_interface

title: Step Field Transition Tile for True Tiles

description.text:
If you are like me and purchased the True Tiles and did a lot of printing before the new upgrade to the openlock system, you may have pasted the original true tiles right on the openlock base provided. This creates a mismatch between the tile types in height, but allows the snapping of the two together.
I have the fix. I have a diagonal tile that steps between the two possible heights. From the Hero's Hoard link you can get the free sample pack. http://www.heroshoard.com/true-tiles which also provides the clip that is used for openlock using the 1 1/4 inch Wyloch tile sizes, also called True Tiles. The diagonal tile with the base and without are included.
The picture with the three tiles gapping to the base were taken on a curved surface and were not warped as it appears in the picture with all three.

title: CR-10. CR-10-S4 Filament Spool Adapter Bushing

description.text:
UPDATE: June 25, 2017 I.D. Was enlarged on 3 pieces to 33.48mm. Some feedback brought to my attention the shaft diameter on their printer was 33mm. Creality did change the design on latest printers. I should have measured the change when shipping the printers out. :) Both versions are available here. If you cannot measure yours, print the end cap part with larger I.D. of 33.48. It may be looser, if you have an early design, but it will help you check. BTW, I.D. stands for inner diameter.

UPDATE: April 7, 2017 I.D. Was enlarged on 3 pieces by 0.31 mm. Some feedback suggested it was a tight fit. This should help.

I consider this a must print, if you own a CR-10, CR-10-S4, Afinibot A31 (Same as CR-10).

There are three files. The first File is the MacEwen3D logo's bushing. The second and third file has additional adapters which can be used to securely mount various brands of filament spools, which are narrower (Protopasta, and smaller inner diameter, E-sun, as well as Hatchbox, and many others_. This will also print well with a 0.8mm nozzle, for speed. 0.4mm nozzle will allow crisper text. (No one will see it.) You should need no cleanup.
PLA, is just fine.

Helping out.

-Ryan MacEwen

author: MakerBot

description.text:
Who hasn't always wanted their own cuddly pet worm, but were put-off by the slime? Hermie at full scale is 20mm (3/4") in diameter, and as long as you like (48 reg. segments will make him about 65cm overall- over 2 feet long)! You will also need some .5mm elastic bead-cord, and a small hook or piece of wire to put him/her together. Print him in color or paint her like I did. This is my first model using meshmixer.
Some quick earthworm facts (that I learned while creating this):

-In one acre of land, there can be more than a million earthworms.
-The largest earthworm ever found was in South Africa and measured 22 feet from its nose to the tip of its tail.
-Earthworms have the ability to replace or replicate lost segments. This ability varies greatly depending on the species of worm you have, the amount of damage to the worm and where it is cut.
-Baby worms are not born. They hatch from cocoons smaller than a grain of rice.
-Even though worms don’t have eyes, they can sense light, especially at their anterior (front end). They move away from light and will become paralyzed if exposed to light for too long (approximately one hour).
-If a worm’s skin dries out, it will die (it breathes through it's skin).
-Worms are hermaphrodites. Each worm has both male and female organs.
-Worms can eat their weight each day.
-Worms have 5 "hearts".
-4 out of 5 people haven't read this far, you are special.

Printer:

scratch built

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

10-12%

Notes:

All head pieces are combined to run together, as well as 12 segments. The head segments are also included separate in a zip file.
Supports are only required under the tip of the head, and the butt.

Putting him/her together:

1) Tie .5mm elastic cord around the eye on the bottom of the head.
2) Thread pieces onto cord (except for the butt). Put about 4-5 regular segments between the head and the clitellum (the puffy-bit).
3) Stretch cord firmly to determine length, and tie end to hook.
(hook should be kinda tight against body at this point, holding pieces together firmly with a bit of stretch left)
4) Attach hook to butt (see photo).
Now he-she's ready for hugs!

description.text: You know how people say it's not rocket science to describe something that's easy to do? Well, getting a rocket off the ground is rocket science. No matter how tired you are, do not use this in your latte. Crate - Pack your gear in these fire-retardant crates, which can withstand extreme temperatures and 6 Gs of pressure. What to pack? description.text:
This is a remix. I rebuilt the model to be printed in vase mode (single spiral layer).

I had to modify the original model so its not exactly like whats in the game any more. Unfortunately it would be impossible to print the original in vase mode. So I modified the lower legs to accommodate a flat bottom and I converted the holes in the fins into dimples rather than through holes. I also modified the curve at the top of the fins so vase mode slicing would do a better job at it.

I also extended the height to make a taller container while maintaining the "look". Both STLs are provided.

title: Shopsmith Mark V Bandsaw Coupler
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I acquired an older model Shopsmith Mark V for next to nothing from a lady while on a service call. Several pieces were missing, one such piece being the coupler that connects the motor to the bandsaw. Shopsmith sells this adapter for $32, but I'd rather make something than buy it if I'm able. As you can see, my first coupler was made out of PVC pipe and epoxy. I've been using that coupler for over two years now with no trouble. Now that I have a 3d printer, though... why not print a new one?

Before you print the full coupler, you may want to print the test piece and make sure that the sizing is correct for your connector. The coupler may need to be sized up just a smidge for a snug, yet secure fit.

Also, look at your metal connectors. You will notice that one of mine has four points whereas the other has five. If both pieces are identical on your setup, this coupler will not work.

Tevo Tarantula

title: HEX snap tiles - For Art, Fabric, Education or Toy?

description.text:
(Update 4/14/2017: Added a few more array shapes).

This is a hex tile building toy that I made for kicks. It still needs a bit of work but it has been fun to play with so I'm sharing it.

Printing these as single items is pretty easy, but printing the larger array prints will require a more challenging printer calibration and resolution. I suggest starting with groups of 4 items at a time and later work up to the array print - unless you are really confident in your printer's capabilities.

The HEX tiles easily click together, but as you start to connect tiles with 3 or more joints you will notice that things can get a little tricky and when you have fat fingers like me the parts can break (especially crumbly PLA) when connecting.

Next steps: I think that these will work great in PETG or ABS for my next iteration. Also a flex material would probably greatly increase the capabilities of this building thingy.

Let me know if any of you have tips for improvements or requests for modified versions to accommodate your buckyballs, armor, neck ties, evening gowns, or whatever.

Note also that this is a work in progress, I'll likely be tweaking the design for strength and flexibility in the future.

Printer:

Maker Select i3 and PowerSpec Ultra

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 to 0.15

Infill:

20% to 30%

Notes:

To print as single items (or a suggested group of 4 at a time):
You can get away with 0.2 resolution if you print these as single items (the non-array files). Duplicate in your slicer software if you want to create a few at time.

To print the array items:

  1. Set Resolution to 0.1 (0.15 sometimes worked for me).
  2. Make sure your print bed is very level and has good plate adhesion.

title: MP Select Mini 40mm part cooling duct for E3D zero-offset mount

description.text:
I don't like the clip-on side-fan mounts as they seem flimsy and I didn't like how the other bolt-on side-mounted fan ducts required that the hotend get pushed so far forward. I liked the home position of this hotend mount: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1835673 and the general idea of this fan mount: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1778384, so I adapted the idea to fit the zero-offset mount. I also needed the fan to sit just far enough forward to not interfere with the x-gantry I have at the end of the x-axis, so that's covered too.

Print the zero-offset mount linked to above (the first link). Swap out the clamping piece for this one. Use an M3 screw to attach the duct. (Flip the bracket piece so it's flat-side down. Not sure why it oriented itself that way.)

MP Select Mini

description.text:
Recommeded Parts:

-- For the power set up, these are my recommendations:
  • Motors: link
  • ESC:link
  • FC: link

DMR Oval Canopy:

This is for the new style of plates from DMR. It's compatible with any D-Obsession accessories, for anyone interested in making accessories or mounts the last 2 standoffs are set 20mm apart. For best results I printed the oval parts in TPU at 120% extrusion multiplier, 3 walls all around and 30% infill with supports.

This is a copy of the outside lights as seen in the Jardin de Cactus by Cesar Manrique in Lanzerote (scaled).
In the latter part of his life Manrique promoted sustainable tourism in his home island of Lanzerote. He created a number of varied tourist attractions combining Art, Architecture and Nature. He was one of too few people to provide a crossover between Art and Engineering. A subject that I'm passionate about.
http://www.cesarmanrique.com/index_i.htm
If you get the chance to see his creations first hand then don't turn it down, it's an inspiration. It's how I spent Christmas!
Regarding the openSCAD Model. It was my first use of this tool and I know it's not a great job, that comes from starting without a plan and not knowing what you're doing! openSCAD itself is great, if you think it looks a bit daunting set yourself a day aside to learn it, you won't look back.

title: BMW CD53 Volume/Power Knob fix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Do you have an CD53 BMW with a radio that has a broken volume knob? This is a part to fix that.

The CD53 radio has a volume knob that you push to power on/off the radio. It seems common for this to get broken with too hard a push and you will no longer be able to turn the radio on or off. The cause is the white plastic support for the knob encoder that breaks where the knob back screws in. The part is a duplicate of the factory one with stronger bosses where the screws thread into the plastic.

You will need to take the radio almost completely apart to install this part.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Ultimate

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.4mm line width, .2mm layer

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed with round support pegs towards the bed

Use a filament that can withstand high temperatures. I used ASA but ABS would work as well. High temp PLA would also likely work but you might need to expand the screw holes a bit.

author: eighty6

remixed_from.author: 1sPiRe
remixed_from.title: D-Bot Carriage Rear Plate with Adjustable Belt Tensioner

title: 3-wheeled or Linear Railed Modular X-carriage (D-Bot Core_XY 3D Printer)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
WATCH IT: I made a new Rear Plate, see below.

A print-carriage on 3 wheels or on a Linear Rail, to use with 3D-printers which use V Slot Extrusion rails, like D-Bot, J-Bot, etc.

3-Wheeled: The usual lower 2 wheels are replaced with 1 wheel, which also has an easy way of adjustment of the pressure with which the 3 wheels are in contact with the rail, to prevent unwanted movements of the carriage. Works nicely, but:

Linear Rail: Now the 2 upper wheels are replaced with a 400mm MGN9 rail + MGN9H block, just to know whether that gives just that bit improvement.
At this moment I'm waiting for delivery of materials for it, but the printed mounts look ok.
Just replacing the wheels etc. with it and the "Linear Rail MGN9 Mount" should do the trick, without any other changes.
I think it is a good idea to keep the Lower Bridge with the original "3rd Wheel" in place, t
o check eventual sideways movement (Y-direction) of the lower parts. But I provide a "Lower Bridge without Wheel" for those who think that's too much. ;-)

The whole thing was inspired by and remixed from the famous and incredibly documented D-Bot of spauda01.

But check: the plates are still 12mm wider and 7mm higher than the original of spauda01, because that gives somewhat easier access for (mounts of) accessories.

State of affairs on october 13th, 2017:
The basic components haven't changed since march/april, most mounts have.(that has changed as of 12-02-18, see below.
I could not get the Direct Drives Mount to perform as I wished. I thought it looked nice
and I felt sorry etc., but when I saw the Zesty Nimbles I decided to chuck it.
I felt that I never could get a bit of speed with enough accuracy with all that mass on
top, even with lighter steppers (which again didn't have enough power to drive the filament
securely without some gear box, adding more mass).
I prefer printing parts above buying them, but this time I decided to go for this concept which combines the best of 2 worlds: stepper on the frame and a light gearbox on the X-carriage, hopefully tightly enough connected in both directions with that cable.

So you'll find modules for 2 ways of using the E3Dv6, the Cyclops, the Chimera: with bowden tubes and with Nimbles. The diamond mount for bowden tubes only.
There is a different fanduct for each setup, mounted on a common vertically adjustable slider. I chose for this solution to get as close as possible to the various hot ends. (When too close: easy to clip them a bit). These ducts are leaner then a previous version.

At the moment I don't use the cable chain any more. It looks nice perhaps, but I still doubt whether it gives real advantage above other ways of conducting cables etc.
With the nimbles there are 8 less wires to bring to the carriage, that convinced me to skip it, but I could easily imagine it still being of use in other configurations.

For mounting the E3Dv6 with a nimble I used the "Adapter for Single Nimble and V6 on a D-Bot" by ZestyTech, published Sep 13, 2017,
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2531767.
For mounting the Chimera/Cyclops with 2 single nimbles I made the "Cyclops-Chimera Mount for 2 Nimbles on an original D-Bot and the 3-Wheeled X-Carriage" by printingSome, published Oct 8, 2017, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2574741.
I preferred to buy 2 single nimbles in stead of the Dual Nimble in order to be more flexible for future endeavors.

But of course you can use the "D-Bot Chimera/Cyclops adapter for the Dual Nimble using the printingSome carriage" by ZestyTech, published Jul 30, 2017, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2459458 too.
The corresponding fan ducts fit here also.

N.B. The above sounds like I have commercial links with Zesty, but I don't. I am experimenting with those nimbles, have not even got really satisfactory results at the moment, without knowing what I do wrong, but I think they form a good proposition.

For the pictures of the various setups I used "mockups" from "Diamond Hotend parts" by kharar, published Mar 24, 2015, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:720520,
"E3D V6 HotEnd CAD Models (Includes all 3 versions)" by lXGaimMasterXl, published May 24, 2014, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:341689, "Mockup of the Zesty Nimble: Lightweight direct drive extruder" by ZestyTech, published Oct 22, 2016, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1843195 and a mockup of a 20x40mm V-slot of Openbuilds which I can't find at the moment. Thanks.

I replaced all history from this page with this overview, it was too much, and also somewhat rewrote the "Notes" (where you can find tips about the assembly etc.)

Edit (10/21/17): added some parts for a Linear Rail, changed this text and the Notes accordingly.
Edit (10/29/17: V2 of Linear Rail Mount (V1 did agree with the nimbles) and added a M3-Nut_mount, to adapt to the new situation. Notes V6a explain it all.
Edit (11/10/17): V6c even better ;-) Added a Nimble_Stepper_Mount, to create more mounting possibilities for the stepper motor without losing any printing space. Tweaked the M3-Nut_mount a bit for easier placing ->v1
Edit (11/27/17): I saw I forgot to remove a warning in the Notes about the linear guide I did build in -> V6d. I works nice and I am going for the same in the Y-direction. ;-)
Edit (12/13/17): I replaced M3-nut_mount-v1.stl with M3-nut_mount-v3.stl, because it was too big, i.e. too little tolerance towards the rail. I flattened it at the side. See to it that you keep that flattened place down, parallel to the 20x40 rail, when fastening. When you have already printed the things I advise you to file 1-1.5mm from the side, when you experience some resistance here and there, whilst riding the X-carriage
Edit (13/02/18) I added a new Rear Plate: "CarriageRear(Belt_Tensioner_Version)", inspired on "D-Bot Carriage Rear Plate with Adjustable Belt Tensioner" by 1sPiRe, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2376442. The most important feature would be that one can adjust the angle between the X-axis and the Y-axis by adjusting the belt-tensions with bolts. While the effect on that angle in practice is less then I expected it makes it also easier to (un)mount and adjust the tension on the belts. With it come the "Belt_Tensioner" and a new Part 2 of the fan mounts the "Fan_Mount_Pt2-Belt_Tensioner_Version" because the other one didn't fit any more. That has become better to mount in the process. All fan mounts Pt1 fit on this, with only a 4mm bigger distance from the hot end.
I suppose that in time I will remove the older rear plate, because I consider this one far better, despite the fact that it needs a bit of t.l.c. after printing without support to get a nice and easy fit of the tensioner into its house. See also the Notes.

comments.text:
Thanks. ;-)
I found that the easiest way to feel when that lower wheel is just right is when one has uncoupled the motors. Then you can really feel the difference when adjusting the bolt.
Too late for the moment for you, alas, but right now I am busy with a back plate with belt tensioners. With these it is much easier to loosen the belts, but, more importantly, to easily adjust the tension in those things with respect to eachother. Which is important for the angle between the X-axis and the y-axis. But that is something else, of course. ;-)
comments.author: Keshan

comments.text:
I finally found the answer to several mysterious problems
when I disassembled the carriage last night I found the 3rd wheel support is snapped inside the carriage, the stepper motors dragged the carriage along the X axis and managed to finish a 4 hours print :o, but screw holes are not in perfect circle :D
plus 3 out of 4 belt clamps were also snapped (fortunately not totally broken, so the belt is still tight on)

title: Otto MK3, Duel Bowden Extruder Mount with Auto Leveling
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: Big Update today. I'm dropping the Otto MK2 and uploading the Otto MK3. For many reasons the MK2 is not a usable part. I will be uploading the SKP and STL files for the MK3. This will provide an assembled model to view and the google sketch file needed to make all the different STLs. In addition, I will leave the SKP file up for those who need to change it for their rig. I've not printed this version %100 yet. I've made a few changes already and I'm currently reprinting parts right now.

INTRO:
This is my take on a Duel Bowden Extruder for V6 J-head hot end. It provides direct air from two 50mm x 15mm blower fans for each print head and a third fan for the tips. This is done by mounting two E3D v6 Fan Ducts directly to the printer mount and pushing air through the body of the mount. There is also a auto bed leveling mount on the rear. I've also made a notch at the top where the J-head mounts to accommodate a thermistor to monitor the temperature at the point where the metal meats the ABS. I don't know at this time if it will be functional and/or useful. I intend to try and print more exotic materials than just PLA and ABS, so the temp is going to have to get much higher than 250C. If you decide to do the same, make sure your using a full metal J-head.

This build does not conform to any known printer model that I know of. Meaning that you may need to edit the file to get it to work with your guide rails. I'm doing my own custom printer for fun and I'm trying to design as many of the parts myself.

I welcome any comments, especially printer settings. Use at your own risk.

Items needed:
M3 screws of various sizes (I will be more specific when I know it works)
three 50mm x 15mm blower fans
two E3D v6 Fan Ducts
one 8mm Approach Sensor
Four Ball Bushing Linear Motion 8mm x 15mm x 24mm

description.text:
Cut two strips of weatherproof led's. (I removed the weatherproofing, but you could keep them on if you'd like)

Wired direct to PSU. Will at some point in the future incorporate an on/off switch.

PLA seems to warp a little as the LED's heat up over extended period. May be more suitable for ABS/PETG.

First picture shows realistic amount of light generated from the light bar. No more need to use a flashlight to watch the nozzle.

A 4 and 6 Button macro pad that use an arduino Pro Micro as the controller an your flavor of cherry mx/gateron style switches

to assemble I used 4 m3x16 screws and nuts

To wire the switches up to an arduino Pro Micro wire a common ground wire to a single pin of every switch and then run one wire per switch to a pin on the arduino.

To code it use the arduino IDE and this guide https://www.sparkfun.com/tutorials/337

title: terraPin Leica Thread Mount Pinhole Body Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a Leica Thread Mount (LTM, or M39) pinhole body cap for Leica, Russian, and Japanese rangefinders, among others. This is a great way to experiment with pinhole photography using a vintage Russian rangefinder like Zorki, FED, or Zenit. The film transport system in a mass-produced camera is vastly superior to the usual method of overwinding or guessing with homemade cameras.

These cameras can often be found on eBay for less than US$20, in fine shape. Even if the shutter durations are incorrect, provided the BULB setting ("B") works, you're in business. Use a standard locking cable release to minimize jostling the camera during an exposure. Another concern with older fabric shutter curtain cameras is small pinholes in the shutter cloth. A flashlight can disclose this. if you can take the back off the camera (Leicas and some older Russian rangefinder do not let you view the back of the curtain directly. If you are shopping for a rangefinder for this purpose, I like the FED2 model.

This lens system has a Body Flange Distance of 28.8 mm, the pinhole cap puts the aperture at that distance from the film, for a so-called focal length of 28.8 mm. The viewfinder in the camera is designed for a 50mm lens, so keep in mind that the viewfinder will only show you what is in the center of the frame.

I use a 0.23 pinhole, and shoot at a nominal f/135 f-number. If you use a more commonly sourced 0.20 mm pinhole, try f/155 for starters, or add a half stop to the durations on the exposure chart. The threads were accurately modeled in OpenSCAD, but remember they're plastic, so use a light touch when threading for the first time.

As always, test your filament for opacity before 3D printing cameras or parts. Ask me how I know this.

Here's a link to all the pictures I have and will continue to take with this camera

The body spacers allow for thread adapters if your camera has a 3/8" tripod mounting point instead of the modern 1/4-20 thread.

Interestingly, I called this the "мутант", Russian for mutant, but I had problems with STL corruption when named with Cyrillic letters. Not sure if it was TinkerCAD, or Slic3r, but I quit doing it.

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license, with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design. .

LulzBot

No

as solid as possible for opacity

I use a bit of gaffer tape to hold the pinhole on the back of the cap, but electrical tape, or black masking tape would be appropriate. Don't forget to blacken the backside of the pinhole to minimize reflections.

description.text:
Update: Did not have but 1 spare bones red for the center waiting on Amazon to come through but here is a print. I honestly love this spinner, has a good feel to it. The green colored print is AIO robotic PLA- good stuff in my opinion. Always has printed well on the MP Mini (used for the photo) at 205°C and 55°C on the bed.

Hello again my fellow plastic pushers....- Here is a simple yet uncommon design using conic curves in Fusion 360. Takes the standard bearings we all use. I typically used Bones Red or now I prefer Yellow jackets with the cheap knockoffs in the out rings. If you need some bearings help me out and buy them below off amazon. I would appreciate it.

Caps from 2ROBOTGUY on his nice Tri Fidget Spinner Toy.

If you need some supplies:

Center Bearings: http://amzn.to/2nqMSqF

Outer Bearing: http://amzn.to/2nqTFkg ($8.29 for 16 bearings)

Great Oil for printer shafts and spinner bearings: http://amzn.to/2n7ERTX (less is more)

AIO Filament: http://amzn.to/2np5JRp

  • I use the oil in a syringe and add just a drop on the bearing after cleaning with alcohol, on the printer do the same just a few drops per linear rail.I love this oil and it is a five star product in my option as well. Even if you don't use my link you should give it a try.

No

description.text:
a small clip for holding frisbee disc outside of your backpack. Using small ring or karabiner to attach it onto your bag.

I used to use another design of frisbee clip to bring my disc daily. Making more durable but more secure clip is a goal of this project. To hold the disc tight and make it easily detachable from the disc, I added the ring over the tail of the clip. By holding the ring with your finger, you can easily get your disc removed from the clip.

I tested the clip with discraft ultrastar 175g but it may also fit to innova pulsar or Wham-O by scaling +- 5%.

Please give any comments or tips for improvement.

author: MakerBot

description.text:
THE AGE OF EMPIRES II TOWN CENTER

..is finally on Thingiverse!



After a quick search, I found that AOE architectural models were not readily available online. Age of Empires was a classic computer game back in my childhood and I was a big fan of these models so I decided to design one myself. This is not an exact model but it's close to an actual replica. It has taken over 5 hours of meticulous work to design this. Please do share, print or collect if you like this model and I would love it if someone would make it and post it here on Thingiverse under the 'I Made One' section. The design could be completed because of numerous pictures of the original model itself on the Internet. Thank you so much, you wonderful wonderful humans!

Model Update [09/13/2017] v1.2 Thing Files section updated with plane-cut sections for the feasibility of printing. Another model for the Main Dome of the Town Center added for user who want to print without much supports. After printing all the pieces, you can join the parts using a PLA compatible glue.

Photo Update [09/18/2017] v1.1 Photos obtained from my friend Jeff who printed this in one piece on Tevo Delta with Simply3D as the slicer at 200 micron layer height. The grass bottom is just a small square of artificial turf that fits the model. You can request your own 3-D model for printing by visiting Jeff's hub on 3DHubs. I am sure you will be delighted with his service!

Photo Update [09/25/2017] v1.1 Product Shoot esque photos uploaded. Notice the salmon skin artifacts on the roof of the model caused because of the humongous Tevo Delta.

General Model Information

This is a top to down design based on plans from the original model. The model was started from the Roof tops and was completed with supports on the lower legs. It contains 40+ different bodies which were eventually fused together to obtain a complete, one-piece model.

The model fits inside a 15x15x15 box and most readily available, commercial as well as non-commercial printers should manage to print this. There are no fancy details which might cause a problem with perimeter wall thickness or so. Everything (hopefully!) fits inside a hobby printer's limitations.

print_settings.Notes:: MAKE SURE YOUR FILAMENT IS OPAQUE!

title: terraPin Box Turtle 4X5 Pinhole Camera
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
One Sheet; One Shot!

The terraPin Box Turtle is designed for 4X5 sheet film or photographic paper and consists of only four 3Dprinted parts. The front and back halves slide together to sandwich a sheet of film 75 mm (or 35mm) from the pinhole. The shutter is designed around four (4) rare earth magnets, 8mm x 3mm, that hold the shutter in place and work as pivot points when snapping the shutter open or closed. Behind the shutter, the pinhole is mounted with a locking cam-clamp.

All photos by Moni Smith using either Fujifilm Neopan Acros 100 B&W film, or Kodak Ektar color negative film.

Expanded information and instructions coming soon!

Box Turtle 75
focal length 75 mm
pinhole 0.30 mm diameter
f/256

Box Turtle 35
focal length 35mm
pinhole 0.20 mm diameter
f/215 (nominal)

Photos are of early prototype, STLs differ in detail.

NOTES

  • Added 35mm wide angle version
  • Revised shutter and pinhole_clamp to work with both 75 and 35mm versions
  • Added some light-trapping to front of camera, to minimize light leaks from box joint.
  • Added small indexing pips to hold pinhole_clamp in position w/o glue

ATTENTION
This work is licensed under the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license. This license applies only to the files and documents available for download from the Thing Files section of this Thing.
All other related content (photographs, videos, and verbiage such as contained in "Description" or "Instructions" ) are excluded from this license, with all rights reserved, unless specifically available for download This notice constitutes a clarification, not a change, to licensing for this design.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25 mm / layer as printed

Infill:

20-50% for strength

Notes:

Print this tool to MAKE SURE YOUR FILAMENT IS OPAQUE!

ASSEMBLY
  • four (4) rare earth magnets, 8mm x 3mm
  • pinhole 0.30 mm diameter for 75mm Box Turtle; 0.20 mm for 35mm version
  • 1/4-20 flanged nut for tripod nut
  • epoxy for mounting magnets and tripod nut
  • Super Glue or other Cyanoacrylate glue for mounting pinhole and locking pinhole_clamp
  • Magic Marker / Sharpie for blackening backside of pinhole, magnets in body
  • flat black paint for reducing reflections if your filament is shiny. Cheap insurance.
  • razor

Use a razor to shave off any ridges from tape on the hot bed. Especially around the pinhole/shutter area. You want the shutter to sit absolutely flat on the front of the camera.

The location of the magnets should be obvious. Orient them the same at both ends, so that it doesn't matter if the shutter blade is upside-down or rightside-up.

The "pinhole_clamp" is a clever bit of snap-fit joinery that twists into position to hold the pinhole against the back of the front half. Carefully secure the pinhole on the clamp with some Super Glue. The clamp will only go on one way. It rotates counter-clockwise to lock. Two tiny nubbins stand proud to lock the clamp in position. You should be able to pop it free if you want to monkey with your aperture. See photo.

The fit of the two halves is snug, Open and close the sliding joint slowly to avoid damaging your pinhole. It will work looser with a little use.

After adding the light trapping around the lip of the front, the two halves will only slide together properly in one configuration. The tripod nut on the bottom of the BACK will be opposite the thing:2206746 lettering on the top of the FRONT. These surface features can be discerned by touch in a changing bag.

Simple tools work great!

I designed this camera to be used for generations. I could have made it much flimsier, but I believe that tools need to be robust and durable. It should withstand a fall to the floor and other hazards. I designed it 100% in Tinkercad. Took me a couple hours total design time with a few revisions. Try it, if you haven't!

If you have a micrometer or digital caliper, you can easily make an accurate pinhole.

description.text:
Chinese Zodiac for 3D Printing.
The Chinese animal zodiac, or shengxiao (/shnng-sshyaoww/ ‘born resembling’), is a repeating cycle of 12 years, with each year being represented by an animal and its reputed attributes. Traditionally these zodiac animals were used to date the years.
The 12 Animals of the Chinese Zodiac
In order, the 12 animals are: Rat, Ox, Tiger, Rabbit, Dragon, Snake, Horse, Goat, Monkey, Rooster, Dog, Pig. Each year is associated with a zodiac animal.

description.text:
This is a 3D printed case for the LimeSDR v1.4s variant. It has been remixed from this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2160863.

Added the following enhancements:

  • Modified to properly fit the LimeSDR v1.4s variant
  • Added heat dissipation grills
  • Exposes up to 12x SMA connectors with easy to mount non-turning cut-outs
  • Added option for CLK_IN and CLK_OUT
  • Labels under each connector

Tips:

  • Use U.FL to SMA cables with length of minimum 15cm
  • Mount the U.FLs with care on the board.
  • Due to limited U.FL lifetime, avoid multiple snap-ins/snap-outs

Printer:

Cetus3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

65%

Notes:

Printed fine with PLA.

comments.text: Thanks for the case design, excellent work and I didn't care about the floating letter centers too much. Printed great, now if only it would RF shield the LimeSDR. Maybe I'll try aluminum HVAC tape over the whole thing cutting out just the vent holes in the top...

author: kkingkkang05

description.text: Vascular tourniquet set for PMCTA

This is my way of lighting up the Trinus enclosure. I mounted some inexpensive 12V LED strips on 3mm coroplast pieces that are the length of the beams. The coroplast fits 2 lengths of LED strips for extra brightness. I only mounted at 5 of the beams (front bottom and vertical sides + bottom right and left) and it lights the whole enclosure very well. Even at 7-8 volts, there's plenty of light. Two of these holders for each beam does the trick and the coroplast clicks right into it. Needs a bit of soldering but that's just part of the fun. It's also super easy to remove.

LED strips - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00HSF65MC
You can get some coroplast from Home Depot - http://www.homedepot.com/p/Coroplast-48-in-x-96-in-x-0-157-in-White-Corrugated-Plastic-Sheet-CP4896S/205351385 - it comes in a pretty huge sheet, so you'll have it for lots of other projects too.

description.text:
SP 99 prop guard.
About 18/19g all 4 guards. (my printer couldn't print <1mm wall, it has made them at 1,12/1,26 mm thick)

There is 4 files : 2 for front guards and 2 for rear guards. They are différent and there is no mark to différenciate them for the moment.

WIP!!

They are a little bit too high and I could make them about 1/2 mm less large i suppose. It needs some real life test aka outside.

Tested : Quite weak in PLA very noisy but functionnal.
Tested : Nylon print : enought resistant for casual crash! but 2 gramms more....

V2 : not yet tested, reinforcement of the arms, test of honey hole!

author: MakerBot

description.text:
My designing of a replacement cable For the digital out port of the GameCube.
Still a working progress and requires parts to be ordered from another site for the solder-able PCB board that fits inside of the print.
It isn't complete yet but it has a half decent tight fit in the physical Port.
It is possible this could be used for a HDMI plug and play mod.
I am currently working on making this so it will be usable for a HDMI plug and play adapter.
porttophalf4.stl is most recent working File for the bottom half but it will work for the top also just working on a better fit.
porttophalf9.stl is a working progress for the top half decent fit just tried one print going to try a second print.
Not every print works might take a few tries to get a good fit because side walls are 0.5 mm wide .
Haven't tried wiring in an HDMI mod-chip yet.
Location of where can order The Chip
https://oshpark.com/shared_projects/7QCoP0Si

author: Panzeria

title: RPG Runes for easy game play

description.text:
These are very basic two side dice for Roll Playing Games. Also, their intent are for simple, short RPG games. A little background perhaps: We do regular hikes, and to fill the time we play 40k or other universe RPG's. In the past we made do with simple flat rocks with tape on one side, so i designed us upgrades.

The way we play:
The GM rolls the dice, any number between 1 to six of them, depending on the difficulty of the action - one di is very difficult, 6 very easy. If two players combat, they can each roll 3 dice to determine the outcome of the battle, same with NPC's. As i said, these are for simple games with no character sheets or upgrades between games (campaign style). However, if you feel you want to add additional campaign rules....

I designed 3 different stones, and doubled it to six. The idea was to have a Rune Bone type dice, to kind of keep with the RPG feel, and the feel of camping in the wild.

Hope you enjoy.

I should add, they are 2cm in length, by 1cm wide by 6mm thick. The I on the one side is 1mm deep, I painted myne black by filling the I in with black paint, just to make it more visible. Also, i printed them in Glow in the Dark ABS, just to find them easier at night (on hikes) and also, so they are more visible for gameplay at night (in the dark of the forest, on quest)

comments.text: OMG. This is an amazing rpg idea. I love the backstory about using rocks and can't wait for my printer to be finished so I can play with my friends after history class. Thx for the amazing model.
